Award.AwardTitle: Identifying mechanisms of symbiosis: Establishment and comparative physiology of siboglinid tubeworm/ bacterial interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Annelid tubeworms belonging to the group Siboglinidae are one of the most successful and diverse animal lineages with obligate symbioses. As adults, these worms lack a functional gut, mouth and anus, and derive energy from bacteria housed within a unique storage organ. Some species within this worm group are well studied due to their dominance at hydrothermal vents and hydrocarbon seeps, whereas other species are poorly known despite a broad distribution in the deep sea. To understand establishment, maintenance, and diversification of these bacterial symbiotic relationships, the investigators will explore the diversity of symbioses within tubeworms and examine molecular processes and mechanisms in host tissue and bacteria in contrasting metabolic pathways that use hydrogen sulfide or methane as a primary energy source. Using candidate species and a range of life-history stages, expressed genes of hosts and symbionts will be surveyed using next-generation pyrosequencing and microarray-based technologies. A goal of the project is to identify important, broad-scale molecular processes directly associated with these symbioses. A bioinformatic, systems-level approach will enable analysis, comparison, and generalization to other terrestrial and aquatic symbiotic systems.
Broader Impacts: All organisms, including humans, are associated with microbial flora. This work will be integral to elucidating how microbial associations have shaped animal biology and evolution. It will also interest those studying invertebrate evolution and diversity, microbial processes and annelids, as well as the symbiosis scientific community. A web-based portal, accessible to K-12 students and researchers, will be developed. This project includes three beginning investigators, a graduate student and a technician. All investigators actively teach and mentor students, seek out personnel from underrepresented groups, and engage in formal outreach efforts. Results obtained from this project will be presented at international meetings and published in peer-reviewed journals. Molecular and computational resources for the study of symbioses will be made publicly available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This proposal’s overarching goal is to understand establishment, maintenance, and diversification of microbial endosymbiotic relationships. To this end, we have been studying Siboglinidae, derived annelid tubeworms comprising four main lineages: vestimentiferans, frenulates, and the genera Sclerolinum and Osedax. As adults, all lack a functional gut, mouth and anus, but instead derive energy from bacterial endosymbionts housed within a unique endosymbiont storage organ. We have been employing a comparative evolutionary perspective to elucidate symbiosis maintenance mechanisms in the sulphur-loving frenulate S. fiordicum, the methane-loving frenulate S. poseidoni, and the vestimentiferan Lamellibrachia luymesi. By adopting a comparative, systems-level approach, we are addressing processes/mechanisms and evolution of this symbiosis. 

To this end, we undertook organismal collection in the Gulf of Mexico in 2009 in the Mississippi canyon and in Norway in 2010. We were obtaining animals to examine with high throughput genomic approaches. Specifically, we have surveyed the genes that are turned on in the animals to compare if different animals use the same basic mechanisms of symbiosis. Or perhaps even closely related animals use very different mechanisms to maintain communication with their symbionts. 

Whereas most symbionts within siboglinid tube worms make their own energy, one symbiont group found within Osedax is a heterotroph (if cannot make energy). Interesting the hemoglobin of this species appears just a little different than other sibglinids suggesting that it may have modified hemoglobin to help with detoxifying hydrogen sulphide (a toxic chemical which surrounds these animals). Using the genomic data we are also exploring how other molecular mechanisms may have been maintained, or modified across evolutionary time. Approximately 5-6 research publications are expected from this work.

Broader Impacts


This work has trained at least 5 undergraduate and 2 graduate students. Several of these student participated on a scientific research voyage in the Gulf of Mexico and were able to travel by submarine to hydrocarbon seeps. There have been multiple public presentations that have featured this work. Some of these tube worms live in hydrocarbon seeps in the Gulf of Mexico and thus have been of interest after the DeepWater Horizon oil spill. A suite of molecular resources for the study of symbioses and annelid research will also be developed and made publicly available.
